intro: Galium sherardifolium, commonly known as the creeping bedstraw, is a perennial flowering plant native to Europe and parts of Asia. It belongs to the Rubiaceae family and is characterized by its prostrate growth habit, with slender stems that root at the nodes. The plant produces small, white or pale pink flowers arranged in clusters, typically blooming from June to August. Its leaves are opposite, ovate to elliptic in shape, and covered in fine hairs. Galium sherardifolium thrives in moist, shaded environments such as woodlands and stream banks.
